subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: The first three are all the same problem. Most strings of text we use every day are raw . That is they don t have script or font information associated with
messageBody:
The first three are all the same problem.
Most strings of text we use every day are 'raw'.
That is they don't have script or font information associated with them.

For example:
Filenames
Usernames (e.g. system, email, ftp accounts)
URLS
Window Titles
Command Line Apps
Text Files
Emails (unless you mandate HTML email)

I gave a figure of 80%, but I think that number is on the conservative side.
I'm sure none of this is new to you, this seems to crop up in most
discussions on Unicode/localisation/internationalisation.
Also, I'm not saying that UTTER/ADO shouldn't be merged, I'd just like
clarification on how they would/should behave 'raw'.

I can't find where Kingsley Read lays out the rules for Shavian, the
best I can say is that I have seen joined up Shavian 'in the wild'.
Does anyone on the list have a link to some authoritative documentation
for Shavian?

Michael Everson wrote:
>
> At 20:20 +0000 2007-11-01, amd64_hacker wrote:
> >Okay, the numbering at the top of the tables threw me off.
> >
> >Context is the problem, how will the computer/font know an UTTER from an
> >ADO in raw text?
>
> Eh? I don't follow you.
>
> >The obvious answer would seem to be to not use the alternate form of
> >UTTER when the alphabet is unknown.
>
> Glyph shaping is font-dependent. Quikscript fonts will be different
> from Shavian fonts.
>
> >The only problem with that is that the alphabet is going to be unknown
> >in about 80+% of cases.
>
> To whom?
>
> >Shavian can be joined up like senior QS, there just hasn't been a font
> >made which does that yet.
>
> Can it? Where is the specification?
> --
> Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com <http://www.evertype.com>
>
>

Most strings of text we use every day are 'raw'.
That is they don't have script or font information associated with them.

For example:

I gave a figure of 80%, but I think that number is on the conservative side.
